choices.text: DGI is more common in females
Classic presentation is with a dermatitis-arthritis syndrome
lesions are small, tender and maculopapular

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding disseminated gonococcal infection (DGI)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Disseminated gonococcal infection (DGI) is uncommon, occurring in only 0.5-3% of untreated cases.

  • DGI results from hematogenous spread of Neisseria gonorrhoeae from mucosal sites (e.g. cervix, urethra) - not direct local spread.
  • M/c in females (Option A ruled out)
  • It classically presents with the triad of:
    • Dermatitis: Crops of small, tender maculopapular → vesiculopustular → necrotic/hemorrhagic lesions (typically on limbs, palms, soles) (Option C ruled out)
    • Tenosynovitis: Often in hands and fingers
    • Migratory polyarthritis: Affects large joints (knees, wrists, MCP/MTP) (Option B ruled out)
  • Suppurative arthritis may occur later (commonly knees)
  • Blood cultures are often positive early but may turn negative in later stages
  • Rare complications: Endocarditis (aortic valve), pericarditis, meningitis
  • Risk factors: Female sex, pregnancy, menstruation, SLE, complement deficiency, IV drug use, HIV

questions.text: Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome is associated with all of the following infections except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Syphilis is not associated with Fitz-Hugh–Curtis syndrome.

Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome (FHCS) is perihepatitis associated with pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).

  • It most commonly occurs as a complication of PID caused by Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae. (Options B & C ruled out)
  • It presents with right upper quadrant pain due to inflammation of the liver capsule (not the parenchyma), often with "violin string" adhesions between the liver capsule and anterior abdominal wall.
  • Genital tuberculosis may rarely cause similar perihepatic adhesions. (Option D ruled out)
  • Diagnosis: Laparoscopy (gold standard) shows violin-string adhesions.

choices.text: Benzathine penicillin G 2.4 million units IM

questions.text: A 28-year-old sexually active male presents with scanty mucoid urethral discharge. Gram stain of the urethral smear is shown below. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient presents with scant mucoid urethral discharge and a gram stain that likely shows no intracellular gram-negative diplococci, suggesting non-gonococcal urethritis (NGU), which is most commonly caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, and also by organisms like Mycoplasma genitalium or Ureaplasma urealyticum.

Azithromycin 1 g orally (single dose) is the treatment of choice for NGU, effective against C. trachomatis.

Sexually transmitted urethritis in males may be gonococcal or nongonococcal.

Diagnostic Criteria for Urethritis:

  • Urethral discharge: Purulent or mucopurulent
  • First-void urine - Dipstick: Leukocyte esterase positive
  • First-void urine - Microscopy: >10 WBCs per high-power field (HPF)
  • Gram stain of urethral swab: >2 WBCs per oil immersion field

Explanation of Other Options:

Ceftriaxone (Option A) is used to treat gonococcal urethritis along with azithromycin, not NGU.

Benzathine penicillin G (Option C) is used for syphilis, not NGU.

Metronidazole (Option D): Used for trichomoniasis or bacterial vaginosis, not first-line for NGU unless Trichomonas vaginalis is confirmed or suspected.

Reference:

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 10th Edition, Page Numbers: 30.1 - 30.13

questions.text: Which of the following is the recommended diagnostic test for Chlamydia trachomatis infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Nucleic acid amplification tests (NAATs) are the preferred and most sensitive diagnostic modality for detecting Chlamydia trachomatis.
  • NAATs detect bacterial DNA or RNA and can be performed on:
    • First-void urine (men)
    • Vaginal or endocervical swabs (women)
    • Urethral, rectal, oropharyngeal swabs (if indicated)
  • NAATs have >95% sensitivity and specificity and are endorsed by CDC as the first-line diagnostic tool.

Explanation of Other Options:

Cell culture (Option A): Historically used, but technically demanding and less sensitive.

ELISA (Option C): Lower sensitivity and specificity than NAAT.

Microscopy (Option D): Not recommended due to poor sensitivity for chlamydia.

choices.text: Oral fluconazole as a single dose
Oral azithromycin as a single dose

questions.text: A 27-year-old female presents with a 3-day history of malodorous, watery vaginal discharge, which worsens after sexual intercourse. A Gram stain of the vaginal discharge is shown below. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical picture is classic for Bacterial Vaginosis (BV), which is not sexually transmitted but often associated with sexual activity.

BV is due to altered vaginal microflora with ↓ Lactobacilli → ↓ lactic acid → ↑ vaginal pH (>4.5). This favors anaerobic overgrowth, especially Gardnerella vaginalis (M/c), Mobiluncus, and Prevotella spp.

Diagnosis is confirmed by Amsel's criteria (3 out of 4 required):

  • Thin, homogenous white vaginal discharge
  • Clue cells on wet mount microscopy (vaginal epithelial cells covered with bacteria)
  • Vaginal pH > 4.5
  • Positive whiff test: Fishy odor after adding 10% KOH (due to release of amines)

Gram Stain Findings in BV:

  • Shows Gram-variable rods, primarily Gardnerella vaginalis
  • Characteristic clue cells: squamous epithelial cells with stippled borders due to adherent coccobacilli

Treatment Options:

  • First-line: Oral Metronidazole 500 mg BID × 5-7 days
  • Alternatives:
    1. Metronidazole 2g single dose
    2. Metronidazole gel 0.75%, intravaginally OD × 5 days
    3. Clindamycin cream 2%, intravaginally at bedtime × 7 days

Explanation of Other Options:

Oral fluconazole as a single dose (Option A): Fluconazole is used for candidiasis, which presents with curdy white discharge and itching.

Oral azithromycin as a single dose (Option B): Azithromycin is used to treat Chlamydia trachomatis, which causes mucopurulent cervicitis, not clue cells.

Oral amoxicillin for 5-7 days (Option D): Amoxicillin is not effective against the anaerobes implicated in BV (e.g., Gardnerella vaginalis, Mobiluncus, Prevotella).

Reference:

Bacterial Vaginosis - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.text: A 26-year-old man presents to the STI clinic with a painless genital ulcer without blisters. There is no history of drug allergy. According to NACP guidelines for syndromic management, which kit should be administered?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

For a patient with a genital ulcer without blisters, syphilis or chancroid is suspected. First-line treatment is the White Kit (penicillin + azithromycin).

If the patient is allergic to penicillin, the recommendation is to switch to the Blue Kit, which includes doxycycline (for syphilis) and azithromycin (for chancroid). (Option B ruled out)

Explanation of Other Options:

Red kit (Option A):

  • For herpetic ulcers (painful genital ulcers)
  • Contains Acyclovir.

Green Kit (Option D):

  • Green Kit (Secnidazole + Fluconazole) is used to treat vaginal discharge syndrome due to:
    • Bacterial vaginosis (covered by Secnidazole)
    • Trichomoniasis (covered by Secnidazole)
    • Candidiasis (covered by Fluconazole)

Reference: NACO guidelines for Syndromic Management of STI

questions.text: What is the drug composition of the Brown Kit under the NACO syndromic STI/RTI management guidelines?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Brown Kit (Kit 8) under the NACO STI/RTI syndromic management guidelines is used for Anorectal Discharge Syndrome, which is typically caused by Chlamydia trachomatis (including LGV strains) and Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • Cefixime 800 mg - single STAT dose, targets gonorrhea
  • Doxycycline 100 mg BD for 7 days - effective against chlamydia, including LGV

This combination provides broad-spectrum coverage for the common etiologies of proctitis, especially in high-risk groups such as MSM.

Explanation of Other Options:

Azithromycin + Cefixime (Option A): This combination is found in Grey Kit (Kit 1). It is used for urethral or cervical discharge, often caused by Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

Metronidazole + Doxycycline + Cefixime (Option B):This is the drug composition of Yellow Kit (Kit 6). It is used for lower abdominal pain in women due to Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID).

Metronidazole + Doxycycline (Option C): This is not a standard NACO kit combination.
It lacks Cefixime, which is crucial for N. gonorrhoeae coverage in anorectal infections.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman presents with multiple cauliflower-like, exophytic growths over the vulva. A biopsy from the lesion shows koilocytosis. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient has anogenital warts (condyloma acuminata), typically caused by HPV types 6 and 11.

  • In pregnancy, cryotherapy is often the first-line treatment, but Trichloroacetic acid (TCA) is also safe and effective.
    • Trichloroacetic acid (TCA) is a topical chemical cautery agent that destroys warts locally without systemic absorption.
  • Podophyllin is contraindicated due to teratogenicity, and Imiquimod is generally avoided in pregnancy as safety is not well established. (Options A & B ruled out)
  • Surgical excision is invasive and reserved for large or refractory lesions. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents with complaints of vaginal discharge and itching for the past 5 days. On speculum examination, the cervix appears as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows a "strawberry cervix", which is characterized by punctate hemorrhages on the cervical mucosa-a classic finding in Trichomoniasis, caused by Trichomonas vaginalis, a flagellated protozoan.

It presents with frothy greenish-yellow discharge, vulvar irritation, and a cervical mucosa with punctate hemorrhages. Diagnosis is via wet mount showing motile trichomonads. Treated with metronidazole.

Vaginal Discharge Syndrome:

Main causes: Candidiasis, Trichomoniasis, Bacterial vaginosis

Explanation of Other Options:

Gonorrhea (Option D):

  • Caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, can be asymptomatic or present with mucopurulent discharge, intermenstrual bleeding, and a friable cervix. It does not typically cause the frothy discharge or strawberry cervix.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by NAAT from a cervical or urine sample.

Reference:

Bacterial Vaginosis - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf
